sections.title: Introduction to Research Methods
sections.summary:
## üî¨ What are Research Methods?

Research methods are **systematic ways** of investigating questions about human behavior and mental processes.

‚Ä¢ Psychology uses **scientific approaches** to understand behavior
‚Ä¢ Research helps us test theories and make evidence-based conclusions
‚Ä¢ Different methods suit different types of research questions

## üéØ Why Research Methods Matter

‚Ä¢ **Reliability** - Can we trust the findings?
‚Ä¢ **Validity** - Do results represent real-life situations?
‚Ä¢ **Objectivity** - Reducing personal bias in research
‚Ä¢ **Replication** - Can other researchers get the same results?

## üìä Types of Research

### Quantitative Research
‚Ä¢ Uses **numbers and statistics**
‚Ä¢ Measures behavior objectively
‚Ä¢ Examples: experiments, surveys with rating scales

### Qualitative Research
‚Ä¢ Uses **words and descriptions**
‚Ä¢ Explores experiences in depth
‚Ä¢ Examples: interviews, observations, case studies

## üß™ The Scientific Method

‚Ä¢ **Hypothesis** - Testable prediction about behavior
‚Ä¢ **Variables** - Factors that can change or be measured
‚Ä¢ **Controls** - Keeping conditions the same
‚Ä¢ **Analysis** - Looking at patterns in the data

sections.title: The Experimental Method
sections.summary:
## ‚öóÔ∏è What is an Experiment?

An experiment is a research method where the researcher **deliberately changes** one variable to see its effect on another variable.

## üîë Key Features

### Independent Variable (IV)
‚Ä¢ The variable the researcher **changes or manipulates**
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Amount of sleep (4 hours vs 8 hours)

### Dependent Variable (DV)
‚Ä¢ The variable the researcher **measures**
‚Ä¢ What is affected by the IV
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Memory test scores

### Control Variables
‚Ä¢ Factors kept **the same** for all participants
‚Ä¢ Prevents them affecting the results
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Same time of day, same room, same test

## üé≤ Experimental Designs

### Independent Groups
‚Ä¢ **Different participants** in each condition
‚Ä¢ Avoids practice effects
‚Ä¢ Risk of participant variables affecting results

### Repeated Measures
‚Ä¢ **Same participants** in all conditions
‚Ä¢ Controls for individual differences
‚Ä¢ Risk of order effects (practice, fatigue)

### Matched Pairs
‚Ä¢ Participants **matched on key characteristics**
‚Ä¢ Combines benefits of both designs
‚Ä¢ Difficult to match participants perfectly

## ‚úÖ Strengths & ‚ùå Weaknesses

**Strengths:**
‚Ä¢ Can establish **cause and effect**
‚Ä¢ High control over variables
‚Ä¢ Can be replicated easily

**Weaknesses:**
‚Ä¢ May lack ecological validity (artificial settings)
‚Ä¢ Ethical constraints limit some research
‚Ä¢ Demand characteristics may affect behavior

sections.title: Observational Methods
sections.summary:
## üëÄ What is Observation?

Observation involves **watching and recording** behavior as it naturally occurs.

## üîç Types of Observation

### Naturalistic Observation
‚Ä¢ Behavior observed in **natural environment**
‚Ä¢ No manipulation by researcher
‚Ä¢ High ecological validity
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Watching children play in playground

### Controlled Observation
‚Ä¢ Behavior observed in **controlled environment**
‚Ä¢ Some variables controlled
‚Ä¢ More reliable but less natural
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Observing behavior in laboratory playroom

## üë• Observer Participation

### Participant Observation
‚Ä¢ Researcher **joins the group** being studied
‚Ä¢ Gains insider perspective
‚Ä¢ Risk of researcher affecting behavior

### Non-participant Observation
‚Ä¢ Researcher **remains separate** from group
‚Ä¢ More objective
‚Ä¢ May miss important details

## üïµÔ∏è Disclosure to Participants

### Overt Observation
‚Ä¢ Participants **know** they're being observed
‚Ä¢ Ethical - informed consent given
‚Ä¢ May cause unnatural behavior

### Covert Observation
‚Ä¢ Participants **don't know** they're being observed
‚Ä¢ More natural behavior
‚Ä¢ Ethical concerns about consent

## üìù Recording Observations

### Structured Observation
‚Ä¢ Uses **predetermined categories**
‚Ä¢ Easier to analyze and compare
‚Ä¢ May miss unexpected behaviors

### Unstructured Observation
‚Ä¢ **Open-ended** recording
‚Ä¢ Rich, detailed data
‚Ä¢ Harder to analyze objectively

## ‚úÖ Strengths & ‚ùå Weaknesses

**Strengths:**
‚Ä¢ Studies behavior in natural settings
‚Ä¢ Can study behaviors that can't be manipulated ethically
‚Ä¢ Rich, detailed data about real behavior

**Weaknesses:**
‚Ä¢ Cannot establish cause and effect
‚Ä¢ Observer bias may affect recordings
‚Ä¢ Difficult to replicate exactly

sections.title: Self-Report Methods
sections.summary:
## üó£Ô∏è What are Self-Report Methods?

Self-report methods involve asking people **directly about their thoughts, feelings, or behaviors**.

## üìã Questionnaires

### Closed Questions
‚Ä¢ **Fixed response options**
‚Ä¢ Easy to analyze statistically
‚Ä¢ May not capture full range of opinions
‚Ä¢ *Example:* "Rate your stress level 1-10"

### Open Questions
‚Ä¢ **Free response** in own words
‚Ä¢ Rich, detailed information
‚Ä¢ Harder to analyze and compare
‚Ä¢ *Example:* "Describe how you feel when stressed"

## üé§ Interviews

### Structured Interviews
‚Ä¢ **Same questions** asked to all participants
‚Ä¢ Standardized and reliable
‚Ä¢ Less flexibility to explore interesting responses

### Semi-structured Interviews
‚Ä¢ **Core questions** plus follow-up questions
‚Ä¢ Balance of consistency and flexibility
‚Ä¢ Most commonly used type

### Unstructured Interviews
‚Ä¢ **Conversation-like** approach
‚Ä¢ Very flexible and detailed
‚Ä¢ Difficult to compare responses

## üìä Designing Good Questions

### Avoid Leading Questions
‚Ä¢ Don't suggest a particular answer
‚Ä¢ *Bad:* "Don't you think homework is stressful?"
‚Ä¢ *Good:* "How do you feel about homework?"

### Use Clear Language
‚Ä¢ Avoid jargon and complex terms
‚Ä¢ Match language to participant's level

### Avoid Double-Barreled Questions
‚Ä¢ Ask about one thing at a time
‚Ä¢ *Bad:* "Do you like school and find it easy?"
‚Ä¢ *Good:* "Do you like school?" + "Do you find school easy?"

## ‚úÖ Strengths & ‚ùå Weaknesses

**Strengths:**
‚Ä¢ Access to thoughts and feelings
‚Ä¢ Large amounts of data can be collected quickly
‚Ä¢ Participants can explain their responses

**Weaknesses:**
‚Ä¢ Social desirability bias (giving 'good' answers)
‚Ä¢ Memory limitations affect accuracy
‚Ä¢ People may not be aware of their true motivations

sections.title: Case Studies
sections.summary:
## üìñ What is a Case Study?

A case study is an **in-depth investigation** of a single individual, group, or event.

## üîç Characteristics of Case Studies

‚Ä¢ **Detailed examination** of one case
‚Ä¢ Uses **multiple research methods** (interviews, observations, tests)
‚Ä¢ Studies behavior over **extended time period**
‚Ä¢ Focuses on **unique or rare** cases

## üß† Famous Psychology Case Studies

### Phineas Gage
‚Ä¢ Railroad worker who survived brain injury
‚Ä¢ Showed link between **frontal lobe and personality**
‚Ä¢ Helped understand brain function

### Little Albert
‚Ä¢ Watson's study of **conditioned fear**
‚Ä¢ Showed how phobias can be learned
‚Ä¢ Raised ethical concerns about research with children

### Patient HM
‚Ä¢ Lost ability to form new memories after surgery
‚Ä¢ Advanced understanding of **memory systems**
‚Ä¢ Showed different types of memory

## üìö Types of Case Studies

### Clinical Case Studies
‚Ä¢ Focus on **psychological disorders**
‚Ä¢ Help understand symptoms and treatments
‚Ä¢ Often used in therapy settings

### Developmental Case Studies
‚Ä¢ Track **changes over time**
‚Ä¢ Study normal or abnormal development
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Language development in children

### Neuropsychological Case Studies
‚Ä¢ Study **brain damage** effects
‚Ä¢ Link brain areas to specific functions
‚Ä¢ Help understand normal brain operation

## üî¨ Data Collection Methods

‚Ä¢ **Interviews** with the individual and family
‚Ä¢ **Psychological tests** and assessments
‚Ä¢ **Medical records** and history
‚Ä¢ **Behavioral observations**
‚Ä¢ **Brain scans** (if relevant)

## ‚úÖ Strengths & ‚ùå Weaknesses

**Strengths:**
‚Ä¢ Rich, detailed information
‚Ä¢ Can study rare conditions
‚Ä¢ Generates hypotheses for future research
‚Ä¢ High ecological validity

**Weaknesses:**
‚Ä¢ Cannot generalize to other people
‚Ä¢ Researcher bias in interpretation
‚Ä¢ Difficult to establish cause and effect
‚Ä¢ Cannot be replicated exactly

sections.title: Sampling Methods
sections.summary:
## üë• What is Sampling?

Sampling is the process of **selecting participants** from a larger population for research.

## üéØ Target Population vs Sample

### Target Population
‚Ä¢ **All people** the research aims to understand
‚Ä¢ *Example:* All teenagers in the UK

### Sample
‚Ä¢ **Subset of people** actually studied
‚Ä¢ *Example:* 100 teenagers from London schools

## üé≤ Probability Sampling Methods

### Random Sampling
‚Ä¢ Every person has **equal chance** of being selected
‚Ä¢ Use random number generator or lottery method
‚Ä¢ **Unbiased** but may be impractical

### Systematic Sampling
‚Ä¢ Select every **nth person** from a list
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Every 10th person on school register
‚Ä¢ Simple but may create bias if list has pattern

### Stratified Sampling
‚Ä¢ Population divided into **subgroups (strata)**
‚Ä¢ Random sample taken from each subgroup
‚Ä¢ Ensures **representative** sample
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Equal numbers of boys and girls

## üéØ Non-Probability Sampling Methods

### Opportunity Sampling
‚Ä¢ Use people who are **easily available**
‚Ä¢ Quick and convenient
‚Ä¢ May be biased (not representative)
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Students in your school

### Volunteer Sampling
‚Ä¢ People **choose to participate**
‚Ä¢ Often through advertisements
‚Ä¢ May attract certain personality types
‚Ä¢ Risk of volunteer bias

### Snowball Sampling
‚Ä¢ Participants **recruit other participants**
‚Ä¢ Useful for hard-to-reach groups
‚Ä¢ May create homogeneous sample
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Studying rare conditions

## üìä Sample Size Considerations

### Large Samples
‚Ä¢ More **representative** of population
‚Ä¢ Greater **statistical power**
‚Ä¢ More expensive and time-consuming

### Small Samples
‚Ä¢ **Cheaper and quicker**
‚Ä¢ May not represent population well
‚Ä¢ Less reliable results

## ‚úÖ Strengths & ‚ùå Weaknesses

**Random Sampling:**
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Unbiased, representative
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå Time-consuming, may be impractical

**Opportunity Sampling:**
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Quick, convenient, cheap
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå May be biased, not representative

**Volunteer Sampling:**
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Motivated participants
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå Volunteer bias, not representative

sections.title: Ethics in Research
sections.summary:
## ‚öñÔ∏è Why Ethics Matter

Ethics ensure that research **protects participants** from harm and respects their rights.

## üìú Key Ethical Principles

### Informed Consent
‚Ä¢ Participants must **understand** what they're agreeing to
‚Ä¢ Know the purpose, procedures, and risks
‚Ä¢ Can **withdraw at any time**
‚Ä¢ Special considerations for children

### Right to Withdraw
‚Ä¢ Participants can **leave the study** at any point
‚Ä¢ No pressure to continue
‚Ä¢ Data can be withdrawn after participation
‚Ä¢ Must be clearly explained before study begins

### Protection from Harm
‚Ä¢ **Physical harm** - no dangerous procedures
‚Ä¢ **Psychological harm** - avoid distress, embarrassment
‚Ä¢ **Social harm** - protect reputation and relationships
‚Ä¢ Benefits must outweigh risks

### Confidentiality
‚Ä¢ Participant **identity kept secret**
‚Ä¢ Data stored securely
‚Ä¢ Results reported anonymously
‚Ä¢ Only researchers have access to personal information

### Deception
‚Ä¢ Should be **avoided** where possible
‚Ä¢ Only acceptable if:
  - No other way to study the behavior
  - No significant harm caused
  - Full debriefing provided afterward

## üë∂ Special Considerations

### Children
‚Ä¢ **Parent/guardian consent** required
‚Ä¢ Child's assent also needed
‚Ä¢ Extra protection from harm
‚Ä¢ Age-appropriate explanations

### Vulnerable Groups
‚Ä¢ People with mental health issues
‚Ä¢ Those in institutions (hospitals, prisons)
‚Ä¢ Extra care needed for consent
‚Ä¢ Additional safeguards required

## üèõÔ∏è Ethics Committees

‚Ä¢ **Review research proposals** before studies begin
‚Ä¢ Ensure ethical guidelines are followed
‚Ä¢ Can reject or request changes to studies
‚Ä¢ Monitor ongoing research

## ‚öñÔ∏è Ethical Dilemmas

### Milgram's Obedience Study
‚Ä¢ Important findings about obedience
‚Ä¢ But caused significant distress to participants
‚Ä¢ **Debate:** Do benefits justify the methods?

### Naturalistic Observation
‚Ä¢ Studying natural behavior
‚Ä¢ But people don't know they're being watched
‚Ä¢ **Question:** When is consent required?

## üîÑ Debriefing

‚Ä¢ **Explain the true purpose** after participation
‚Ä¢ Address any concerns or distress
‚Ä¢ Provide information about findings
‚Ä¢ Offer counseling if needed
‚Ä¢ Opportunity to withdraw data

## ‚úÖ Balancing Ethics and Research

**Researchers must consider:**
‚Ä¢ Scientific value of the research
‚Ä¢ Potential benefits to society
‚Ä¢ Risks to participants
‚Ä¢ Whether ethical alternatives exist
‚Ä¢ Long-term consequences of findings

sections.title: Evaluating Research Quality
sections.summary:
## üîç Key Evaluation Criteria

When evaluating psychological research, we use specific criteria to judge how good a study is.

## üéØ Generalisability

**Can findings apply to other people and situations?**

‚Ä¢ **Population generalisability** - Do results apply to other groups?
‚Ä¢ **Situational generalisability** - Do results apply in other settings?
‚Ä¢ *Example:* Study of London teenagers - can we generalize to all teenagers worldwide?

### Factors Affecting Generalisability
‚Ä¢ **Sample size** - Larger samples usually more generalizable
‚Ä¢ **Sample characteristics** - Age, gender, culture, background
‚Ä¢ **Setting** - Laboratory vs real-world environments
‚Ä¢ **Time period** - Do findings apply across different eras?

## üîÑ Reliability

**Consistency of results when study is repeated**

‚Ä¢ **Test-retest reliability** - Same results when repeated over time
‚Ä¢ **Inter-observer reliability** - Different researchers get same results
‚Ä¢ **Internal consistency** - All parts of test measure same thing
‚Ä¢ **Split-half reliability** - Two halves of test give similar results

### How to Improve Reliability
‚Ä¢ **Standardized procedures** - Same method every time
‚Ä¢ **Clear instructions** - Reduce confusion and variation
‚Ä¢ **Training observers** - Consistent recording methods
‚Ä¢ **Pilot studies** - Test procedures before main study
‚Ä¢ **Multiple measurements** - Average out random errors

## üìä Validity

**Does the study measure what it claims to measure?**

### Internal Validity
‚Ä¢ **Cause and effect** - Does IV really cause DV changes?
‚Ä¢ **Confounding variables** - Other factors affecting results
‚Ä¢ **Participant variables** - Individual differences between groups
‚Ä¢ **Situational variables** - Environmental factors
‚Ä¢ **Researcher bias** - Experimenter expectations affecting results

### External Validity
‚Ä¢ **Ecological validity** - Applies to real-world settings
‚Ä¢ **Population validity** - Applies to other groups of people
‚Ä¢ **Temporal validity** - Applies across different time periods
‚Ä¢ **Cultural validity** - Applies across different cultures

### Threats to Validity
‚Ä¢ **Demand characteristics** - Participants guessing aims
‚Ä¢ **Social desirability** - Giving 'good' answers
‚Ä¢ **Order effects** - Practice, fatigue, boredom
‚Ä¢ **Hawthorne effect** - Behavior changes when observed

## üåç Applicability

**How useful are findings in real-world contexts?**

‚Ä¢ **Practical applications** - Can findings solve real problems?
‚Ä¢ **Educational implications** - How can schools use findings?
‚Ä¢ **Therapeutic applications** - Can findings help treat disorders?
‚Ä¢ **Policy implications** - Should governments change policies?
‚Ä¢ **Economic benefits** - Do applications save money or improve productivity?

### Examples of Good Applicability
‚Ä¢ **Memory research** ‚Üí Study techniques and learning strategies
‚Ä¢ **Social influence research** ‚Üí Understanding compliance and persuasion
‚Ä¢ **Developmental research** ‚Üí Parenting and education practices
‚Ä¢ **Cognitive research** ‚Üí Improving decision-making processes

## ‚öñÔ∏è Ethics in Evaluation

**Was the research conducted ethically?**

### Ethical Strengths
‚Ä¢ **Informed consent** properly obtained
‚Ä¢ **No physical/psychological harm** to participants
‚Ä¢ **Confidentiality and anonymity** maintained
‚Ä¢ **Right to withdraw** clearly explained and respected
‚Ä¢ **Debriefing** provided after participation
‚Ä¢ **Benefits outweigh risks** to participants

### Ethical Weaknesses
‚Ä¢ **Deception** used without proper justification
‚Ä¢ **Psychological distress** caused to participants
‚Ä¢ **Vulnerable groups** not adequately protected
‚Ä¢ **Consent** not properly obtained or informed
‚Ä¢ **Privacy** invaded without permission
‚Ä¢ **Long-term consequences** not considered

## üî¨ Evaluating Different Research Methods

### Laboratory Experiments
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **High internal validity** - Excellent control over variables
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Low ecological validity** - Artificial laboratory setting
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **High reliability** - Standardized procedures
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Limited generalisability** - Often narrow, unrepresentative samples
‚Ä¢ ‚öñÔ∏è **Ethics** - Generally good control, but may use deception

### Field Experiments
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Higher ecological validity** - Real-world settings
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Lower internal validity** - Less control over variables
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Good applicability** - Directly relevant to real life
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Ethical concerns** - Participants may not know they're in study

### Case Studies
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Rich, detailed data** - High applicability for understanding individuals
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Very poor generalisability** - Single cases, cannot generalize
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Low reliability** - Cannot replicate exactly
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **High ecological validity** - Real-life situations and contexts
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Generally ethical** - Usually involves informed consent

### Naturalistic Observations
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Excellent ecological validity** - Natural behavior in natural settings
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Very low internal validity** - No control over variables
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Observer bias** significantly affects reliability
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Good applicability** - Directly relevant to real-world behavior
‚Ä¢ ‚öñÔ∏è **Ethical issues** - Consent problems, especially in covert observation

### Questionnaires/Surveys
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Good generalisability** - Can use large, representative samples
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **High reliability** - Standardized questions and procedures
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå **Validity concerns** - Social desirability bias, self-report limitations
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Good applicability** - Easy to apply findings to populations
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ **Generally ethical** - Easy to obtain informed consent

## üìù Writing Evaluations

### Structure for Evaluation
1. **Identify the method** used in the study
2. **Assess reliability** - Can it be replicated consistently?
3. **Evaluate validity** - Does it measure what it claims?
4. **Consider generalisability** - Who do findings apply to?
5. **Examine applicability** - How useful are findings?
6. **Review ethics** - Was it conducted ethically?
7. **Overall judgment** - Weigh strengths against weaknesses
